text: Solving an Archeological Mystery: Comparing Samples Using Box Plots

Archeologists study past civilizations by excavating ancient settlements. They examine the artifacts of the people who lived there.

On digs in southeastern Montana and north-central Wyoming, archeologists discovered the remains of two Indigenous settlements. They found a number of arrowheads at each site. The archeologists hoped to use the arrowheads to estimate the time period in which each site was inhabited.

The archeologists decide to use the information from samples of arrowhead data from two settlement sites with known time periods where they know the time period. They will compare this with the samples from the unknown time periods.

The archeologists knew that the Big Goose Creek and Wortham Shelter sites were settled between CE 500 and CE 1600. They also knew that the Laddie Creek and Kobold/Buffalo Creek sites were settled between 4000 BCE and CE 500.
